div.p: Greetings. I return to you everything you recently sent and express my immense gratitude to you, most esteemed lord and godfather.
There remains a small sheet of a pasquinade, which I do not return because it is not currently at hand; however, I will send it soon.

Meanwhile, with great sorrow, I have learned that Christoph, your son, has died in the recent expedition of Prince of Orange, for which I deeply sympathize with you and all your family. However, since you are not unaware of how these matters should be received, it is not for me to teach you this.

We have nothing new that is of any significance. Our people have returned from Strasbourg, where they delivered money; but they bring nothing except that the forces of Orange have all dispersed and are causing great distress to the areas neighboring Strasbourg; he himself is said to be walking around the city almost as a private citizen. We hear that the people of Lucerne are restless; they have ordered all their men to be ready. What they are planning, I do not yet understand. I would write more, but I must go to the sermon, and I fear that this messenger, who informed me of his departure too late, may precede me. Therefore, farewell.
Diesbach has set out for Burgundy; he will bring back something.
To the most illustrious man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most faithful pastor of the Zurich church, my honorable lord and dearest godfather.
